Notes: A total of 369 nesting pairs were counted in the 3 census blocks in 2017, from which it was estimated there were 2477 pairs were nesting on Antipodes Island that year. The mark-recapture analysis indicated that on average only 62% of the breeding females in the study population laid in each of the last 4 years, which suggests that the total number of breeding females and breeding pairs is approximately 3945.
References: Elliott, G.; Walker, K. 2017. Antipodean wandering albatross census and population study 2017. https://www.doc.govt.nz/globalassets/documents/conservation/marine-and-coastal/marine-conservation-services/reports/antipodean-albatross-adams-island-2017.pdf

Notes: 509 nests were counted in three areas in 2018. The estimated total pairs breeding on Antipodes in 2018, based on the proportion of the total population nesting in those 3 blocks in 1994–1997, was 3,402 pairs.
References: Elliot, G. & Walker K. (2018). Antipodean wandering albatross census and population study 2018. Prepared by Albatross Research, 18 p.
Elliott, G.; Walker, K. 2020. Antipodean wandering albatross: satellite tracking and population study Antipodes Island 2020. Nelson, Department of Conservation.

Notes: A total of 471 nests were counted in the 3 representative census blocks in 2019. The estimated total number of pairs breeding on Antipodes Island in 2019, based on the proportion of the total population nesting in those 3 blocks in 1994–1997, was 3,148 pairs.
References: Elliot, G. & Walker K. (2019). Antipodean wandering albatross census and population study 2019. Department of Conservation, 27 p.

Notes: 75 nests were present in the Study Area in 2019, so the estimated total number of pairs breeding on Antipodes Island in 2020, based on the proportion of the total population nesting in that area in 1994–1997, was 2714 pairs.
References: Elliott, G.; Walker, K. 2020. Antipodean wandering albatross: satellite tracking and population study Antipodes Island 2020. Nelson, Department of Conservation.

Notes: Counts of Antipodean wandering albatross nests with eggs in February in three areas (Study Area [93 nests], Block 32 [89 nests] and Lower MCBA [124 nests]) extrapolated to island-wide totals from the proportion of nests in these areas during 1994-1996 to the total number counted annually in the same period.
References: Walker, K.; Elliott, G. 2022. Antipodean wandering albatross satellite tracking and population study on Antipodes Island 2021 and 2022. Department of Conservation, Wellington. 28 pp. Typescript.

Notes: Counts of Antipodean wandering albatross nests with eggs in early February in three areas (Study Area [90 nests], Block 32 [74 nests] and total MCBA [274 nests]) extrapolated to island-wide totals from the proportion of nests in these areas during 1994-1996 to the total number counted annually in the same period.
References: Walker, K.; Elliott, G. 2022. Antipodean wandering albatross satellite tracking and population study on Antipodes Island 2021 and 2022. Department of Conservation, Wellington. 28 pp. Typescript.

Notes: Counts of nesting birds along adjacent strips covering each block, carried out in early February, just after completion of egg laying
References: Walker, K.; Elliott, G. 2022. Antipodean wandering albatross satellite tracking and population study on Antipodes Island 2021 and 2022. Department of Conservation, Wellington. 28 pp. Typescript.

Notes: Counts carried out February 2023, just after the completion of egg laying, with observers each searching a 25-m wide strip and counting all nests with eggs in their strip. Coordinates of all nests with an egg recorded by GPS. Accuracy assessed by walking straight transects at right angles to the strips, checking that all nests within 10-15m of the transect have been recorded by GPS, and therefore have already been counted.
References: Parker G, Rexer-Huber K, Walker K, Elliott G. 2023. Antipodean wandering albatross population study 2023. Final report to the Department of Conservation. Parker Conservation, Dunedin. 21 pp.

Notes: Counts carried out in three areas (SA, Block 32, MCBA), representing ~15% of total population, based on the proportion nesting in those areas relative to island wide totals in 1994-97, then extrapolated to the total shown here.
References: Parker G, Rexer-Huber K, Walker K, Elliot G. 2023. Antipodean wandering albatross population study 2023. . Final report to the Department of Conservation. Parker Conservation, Dunedin. 21 pp.

Notes: BirdLife Species Action Plan gives 747 pairs based on colony estimates mostly in 2003, one in 2004 and one in 2005.
Considered unoccupied in the revision of the SAP (Arcos -comp- 2011). There's current evidence of presence of breeders, though no proper prospection has been conducted yet
Monitoring work carried out by SEO/BirdLife with IRBI, IEO, LPO and CNRS

Some islets have been monitored in recent years. In most cases a handful of nests were properly monitored but estimate for total islet based on rough assumptions. For otherr islets just rough assumptions.
Monitoring of nests in some accessible areas, up to 77 in 2013. However, rough estimate for the rest of the island, based on habitat features, rafts, unaccesible sites wher birds do enter,...
Almost 40 nests controlled. Suitable breeding sites, rather unaccessible, in other areas of the islet, likely total population within the given range
No proper prospection of nests, just a few nests found on occasional visits. Based on habitat features, rafts, etc., rough estimate around 50-100 breeding pairs
Revisited in 2016 (chick-rearing period) after 2 decades, detected around 90 nests, guess estimate 170 breeding pairs
References: Serapio et al. 2016; PaCSWG4_Inf_25 Rev 1 Puffinus mauretanicus update_ARCOS et al

Notes: No se ha logrado detectar ningún nido en la zona, si bien no ha habido prospecciones adecuadas. Las estimas previas eran meramente especulativas (escuchas, balsas), y se considera más adecuado, por prudencia, no asumir la nidificación mientras no existan evidencias.
No se ha comprobado la nidificación de forma fehaciente, se estima adecuado no considerar ninguna estima hasta que no exista una prospección adecuada
No se ha comprobado la nidificación de forma fehaciente. Aunque el hábitat es adecuado, se estima prudente no considerar ninguna estima hasta que no exista una prospección adecuada

Sin una prospección adecuada, se hace una reevaluación tentativa en base a los nido conocidos y al hábitat disponible, de cara a informe sobre la especie presentado ante los grupos de trabajo en Nueva Zelanda (septiembre 2017)
References: PaCSWG4_Inf_25 Rev 1 Puffinus mauretanicus update_ARCOS et al

Notes: Prospección en 2021, se detectan 3 nidos ocupados (huevos) y indicios de por lo menos 7 más en zona no accesible. Estima a la baja para el islote.

from: Caroline Icaza Galarza, Dirección de Gestión y Coordinación Marina y Costera, SUBSECRETARÍA DE GESTIÓN M

Notes: En 2015, el albatros de Galápagos frente a los cambios de temperatura registrados, se registró pocos individuos en anidación, igual como mencionó Rechten (1985) en el fenómeno de El Niño de 1982-83 y como ocurrió en 2015(Jiménez-Uzcátegui 2015). La información obtenida de este monitoreo sistemático y programa de captura-recaptura se lo realiza a largo plazo. Por lo tanto, se recomienda continuar con el monitoreo hasta el 2019 para detectar cambios poblacionales y tener un mejor conocimiento en el cambio climático.
from: Caroline Icaza Galarza, Dirección de Normativas y Proyectos Marinos y Costeros

Notes: debido a la presencia del fenómeno de El Niño, como ocurrió en 1982-83 y 1997-98, estas poblaciones pueden disminuir su número poblacional y afectar su tasa reproductiva (Vargas 2006, Jiménez-Uzcátegui et al 2015)
References: Informe Técnico para laFundación Charles Darwin y la Dirección Parque Nacional Galápagos, Gustavo Jiménez-Uzcátegui, DMV

Notes: No se ha logrado detectar ningún nido en la zona, si bien no ha habido prospecciones adecuadas. Las estimas previas eran meramente especulativas (escuchas, balsas), y se considera más adecuado, por prudencia, no asumir la nidificación mientras no existan evidencias.
